description: This virtual science lab uses the My Solar System Lab Simulation app to explore the dynamics of the solar system. Students will engage in a case-study method to investigate the relationships between mass, distance, and gravitational forces in planetary motion.

learningGoals.bigIdea: The gravitational interactions between celestial bodies govern the structure and behavior of the solar system.
objectives: Understand how mass and distance affect gravitational forces.
Analyze the relationship between orbital speed and distance from the sun.
Investigate how changes in mass impact orbital dynamics.
Explore the interactions of multiple bodies within the solar system.
successCriteria: Demonstrate the ability to manipulate simulation parameters effectively.
Accurately document observations and data collected during the simulation.
Make informed predictions based on scientific reasoning.
Engage in critical thinking about the relationships and dynamics within the solar system.

labParts.title: Investigating Gravitational Forces
setup: Open the My Solar System Lab Simulation app.
Set the mass of the sun to 250.0 (10^28 kg) and the mass of a planet to 25.0 (10^28 kg).
Adjust the distance between the sun and the planet to 1 AU.
Start the simulation and observe the motion.
observations: How does the planet's orbit change as you adjust its mass?
What happens to the gravitational force as the distance between the sun and the planet is altered?
How does the planet's speed change in relation to its distance from the sun?
evidence: Document the gravitational force and orbital speed in a CSV file.
predictions: What will happen to the planet's orbit if its mass is increased?
How will the gravitational force change if the distance is doubled?

labParts.title: Effect of Distance on Orbital Speed
setup: Reset the simulation.
Keep the mass of the sun at 250.0 (10^28 kg) and the mass of the planet at 25.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the distance to 2 AU and start the simulation.
Record the planet's orbital speed.
observations: What differences do you notice in the planet's speed at 2 AU compared to 1 AU?
How does the gravitational pull affect the planet's speed at this distance?
Does the planet maintain a consistent speed throughout its orbit?
evidence: Record the planet's orbital speed at both distances in a CSV file.
predictions: How will the orbital speed change if the distance is increased to 3 AU?
What do you think will happen if the distance is decreased to 0.5 AU?

labParts.title: Mass and Orbital Dynamics
setup: Reset the simulation.
Set the mass of the sun to 250.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the mass of the planet to 50.0 (10^28 kg).
Maintain the distance at 1 AU and start the simulation.
observations: How does the increased mass of the planet affect its orbit?
What changes do you observe in the gravitational force exerted on the planet?
How does this mass change impact the planet's speed?
evidence: Document the gravitational force and orbital speed in a CSV file.
predictions: How might the planet's orbit change if its mass were decreased to 10.0 (10^28 kg)?
What would happen if both the sun and planet masses were increased simultaneously?

labParts.title: Exploring Multiple Bodies in the System
setup: Reset the simulation.
Set the mass of the sun to 250.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the mass of two planets: one at 25.0 (10^28 kg) and another at 10.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the distances to 1 AU and 1.5 AU respectively, then start the simulation.
observations: How do the orbits of the two planets interact with each other?
What happens to the gravitational forces acting on each planet?
How do the speeds of the planets compare to each other?
evidence: Collect data on the orbits and speeds of both planets in a CSV file.
predictions: What will happen if the distance between the two planets is reduced?
How might the orbits change if one planet's mass is significantly increased?

description: This virtual lab explores the principles of natural selection using a simulation app to model how different traits affect survival and reproduction in a rabbit population.

learningGoals.bigIdea: Natural selection is a key mechanism of evolution that affects the diversity of life.
objectives: Understand the role of environmental factors in natural selection.
Analyze how specific traits impact the survival of a population.
Evaluate the effects of mutations on population dynamics.
Synthesize data to draw conclusions about evolutionary changes.
successCriteria: Demonstrate the ability to collect and analyze data from the simulation.
Effectively predict outcomes based on specific trait changes.
Articulate connections between environmental factors and trait survival.
Create a comprehensive report summarizing findings and conclusions.

labParts.title: Introduction to Natural Selection
setup: Open the Natural Selection Lab Simulation app.
Select the initial population of rabbits with varying traits.
observations: How do the different traits of the rabbits affect their visibility in the environment?
What do you notice about the initial population's distribution of traits?
How do environmental factors (e.g., food availability) seem to influence the rabbits?
evidence: Record the initial population counts of each trait (fur color, ear type, tooth size).
Capture a screenshot of the initial trait distribution graph.
predictions: Which traits do you think will be favored in the next generation?
How might changes in the environment affect future generations of rabbits?

labParts.title: Simulating Environmental Changes
setup: Introduce a new environmental factor, such as predators.
Run the simulation for 10 generations.
observations: What changes do you observe in the rabbit population over generations?
How do specific traits appear to influence survival rates?
Is there a noticeable shift in the dominant traits among the rabbits?
evidence: Document the population counts of each trait at each generation.
Analyze and record the survival rates of each trait.
predictions: Which traits do you think will decrease in frequency?
How do you expect the population to stabilize in response to the new predator?

labParts.title: Exploring Mutations and Variation
setup: Add a mutation to the rabbit population (e.g., longer teeth).
Run the simulation for 10 more generations.
observations: How does the introduction of mutations affect the population?
What variations in traits do you notice emerging?
Do any new traits become more advantageous?
evidence: Track the occurrences of the new trait and its impact on survival.
Create a graph showing the changes in trait frequency over generations.
predictions: Will the new mutation become prevalent in future generations?
How might these mutations interact with environmental changes?

labParts.title: Analyzing the Data and Formulating Conclusions
setup: Review the data collected from all generations.
Analyze how natural selection has shaped the rabbit population.
observations: What trends do you notice in the data about trait survival?
How do the results support or contradict your initial predictions?
What role did environmental factors play in shaping the population?
evidence: Summarize the data trends in a final report.
Create a visual representation (chart) of trait frequency changes.
predictions: What future changes might occur if environmental conditions shift again?
How could different mutations further influence the population?

description: Virtual science lab exploring natural selection through a simulation of rabbit populations, focusing on adaptations and environmental factors.

learningGoals.bigIdea: Natural selection is a key mechanism of evolution, shaping the diversity of life.
objectives: Understand the concept of natural selection.
Analyze how environmental factors influence survival and reproduction.
Investigate the impact of genetic mutations on populations.
Evaluate data to draw conclusions about evolutionary processes.
successCriteria: Demonstrate understanding of natural selection through simulation.
Correctly analyze changes in population traits over generations.
Effectively document and interpret data from the simulation.
Articulate conclusions based on evidence gathered during the lab.

labParts.title: Introduction to Natural Selection
setup: Open the Natural Selection Lab Simulation app.
Select the initial rabbit population and environmental factors.
observations: What variations exist in the initial rabbit population?
How do the environmental factors affect the rabbits' survival?
What adaptations can you identify in the rabbits?
evidence: Document the initial population characteristics in a table.
Record the environmental factors you selected.
predictions: How do you expect the population to change over generations?
Which traits do you think will be favored by natural selection?

labParts.title: Simulating Changes in Population
setup: Run the simulation for 10 generations without adding mutations.
Observe the changes in population size and traits.
observations: What changes occur in the population size over generations?
Which traits become more or less common?
How do the environmental factors interact with the traits?
evidence: Create a graph showing population size over generations.
List the most common and rare traits after 10 generations.
predictions: What do you think will happen if the simulation continues for another 10 generations?
Will the population stabilize or continue to change?

labParts.title: Adding Mutations
setup: Introduce a mutation to the rabbit population.
Run the simulation for another 10 generations.
observations: What immediate effects do the mutations have on the population?
How do the new traits interact with existing traits?
What role do environmental factors play in the success of these mutations?
evidence: Record the traits and frequencies of the population after introducing mutations.
Document any changes in survival rates of rabbits with new traits.
predictions: How do you think the introduced mutations will affect future generations?
Will some traits become dominant over others due to the mutations?

labParts.title: Analyzing Results and Drawing Conclusions
setup: Analyze the data collected throughout the simulation.
Summarize how natural selection influenced the rabbit population.
observations: What patterns do you observe in the data collected?
How did the introduction of mutations impact the overall evolution of the population?
What conclusions can you draw about natural selection from your simulation?
evidence: Create a summary chart of traits and their survival rates.
Write a brief conclusion about the impact of environmental factors on natural selection.
predictions: What future changes in the population can you foresee based on your data?
How might this simulation reflect real-world natural selection processes?

description: This virtual science lab utilizes the Natural Selection Lab Simulation app to explore the concept of natural selection through a case-study approach.

learningGoals.bigIdea: Natural selection drives the evolution of species over time.
objectives: Identify how environmental factors influence population traits.
Analyze the impact of genetic variations on survival.
Evaluate the role of competition in natural selection.
Understand how mutations contribute to diversity in populations.
successCriteria: Students will correctly document changes in population traits over multiple generations.
Students will articulate how environmental factors influence survival.
Students will demonstrate the ability to collect and analyze data effectively.
Students will make informed predictions about future generations based on observed data.

labParts.title: Environmental Influences on Traits
setup: Open the Natural Selection Lab Simulation app.
Select environmental factors such as 'Wolves' and 'Tough Food'.
Run the simulation for 20 generations.
observations: What changes do you notice in the population traits as generations progress?
How do the introduced environmental factors affect the population?
Are there specific traits that seem to be favored over others?
evidence: Collect data on population traits over 20 generations and document it in a CSV file.
predictions: How might the population change if the environmental conditions were altered?
What traits do you predict will dominate in the next generation?

labParts.title: Genetic Variation and Survival
setup: Start a new simulation with different genetic variations.
Introduce mutations for fur color and ear shape.
Observe the population for 20 generations.
observations: Which genetic variations are most successful in the current environment?
How do these variations affect the overall survival of the population?
Are there any traits that become less common over time?
evidence: Document the success rates of various traits in a CSV file.
predictions: What might happen to the population if a new predator is introduced?
How would the population look if there were no mutations?

labParts.title: Competition and Natural Selection
setup: Adjust the population density settings in the simulation.
Run the simulation for 20 generations with increased competition.
Observe the interactions among the population.
observations: How does increased competition affect the survival of different traits?
Do you notice any specific traits that provide an advantage in competition?
What happens to the population size as competition increases?
evidence: Record the changes in population size and traits in a CSV file.
predictions: What changes might you expect in the traits after several generations of high competition?
If competition decreases, how might the population traits evolve?

labParts.title: The Role of Mutations
setup: Create a new simulation scenario by introducing various mutations.
Observe the effects of these mutations over 20 generations.
Note the traits that arise from these mutations.
observations: What new traits emerge as a result of mutations?
How do these mutations affect the overall fitness of the population?
Are any mutations detrimental to the survival of the population?
evidence: Compile data on the prevalence of mutations and their impact in a CSV file.
predictions: What might happen if all mutations were beneficial?
How would the population look like after several generations with only negative mutations?
